content.description: The figure above shows the position of a moon that orbits a planet in an elliptical path. Two specific locations of the moon, position <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and position <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are labeled.
content.question: As the moon orbits the planet from position <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to position <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is the magnitude of the planet’s force due to gravity exerted on the moon constant? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the masses of the planet and moon remain constant.
Yes, because the elliptical path that the moon travels around the planet is the same for all revolutions.
No, because the tangential speed of the moon is always changing.
No, because the moon’s distance from the planet is always changing.

content.answer: No, because the moon’s distance from the planet is always changing.
